content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! Lets start this week's steering meeting!
(add a :wave: above you show you're here!)
As a reminder, today's goal is to review the document describing our team's ambitions for 2022
This is the doc: https://hackmd.io/Hrl30lX9Q0mbLIT4VkR_UA?view
Please add a :book: here when you start reading, and leave it clicked. Add a :checkered_flag: when you are done reading.
You can leave small comments/questions about the content in the margin of the hackmd.
bigger questions should go at the bottom; i'll add a section
what's the meaning of the emojis?
lets aim to be done reading by 2022-02-18T10:25:00-05:00

Santiago Pastorino said:

what's the meaning of the emojis?

In the document you mean?
:crab:, :woman:‚Äçüíª, üõ†Ô∏è
yes

Santiago Pastorino said:

what's the meaning of the emojis?

Each emoji corresponds to one of the themes in the list of three themes. That probably should be spelled out explicitly.
(sorry, I misspoke up above; I've editted the time entry to say 25 minutes after the hour, which is still not a huge amount of time, but its better than "instantaneous")
wow it looks like a lot of people finished reading sooner than I expected
well if you're done reading, maybe think about questions/topics to discuss, and write them down. I don't want to rush the people remaining.
Okay everyone's done reading now it looks like?
So, lets dig in. I'll first run through the margin comments, to ensure there's no questions about the content itself.
I left responses inline to some of them. E.g., Wesley correctly pointed out a place where an "and" should be "or" instead
and @mw did a great job of catching typos

There was this 11 day old comment from @Wesley Wiser : "Should we frame this as completing approved RFCs or something? I seem to recall phrasing like that in previous years roadmaps" which got moved around
concretely, @Wesley Wiser , are you saying that the Expressiveness initiatives section should say up front "we have this set of RFCs approved, and here are the ones we expect forward. movement on" ?
Yes, exactly!
Okay. I'll make that edit after the meeting
@simulacrum said we should link to https://hackmd.io/YJQSj_nLSZWl2sbI84R1qA in the performance section; let me double check that is the same doc that @nnethercote asked me not to link to yet
yes, it's probably the same doc

I've definitely seen people in the community ask how to do something and the response is "there's this cool RFC #nnn but it's not implemented yet". So it might make sense to align that section with that more clearly.
I'm not sure if we should link yet but it seems like there's probably interesting comments to cite from there, at least.

simulacrum said:

yes, it's probably the same doc

okay. so lets leave it unlinked for now. We can edit the blog post after the fact when @nnethercote feels like its ready
citing comments from it might be a good way to go; I'll try to make time to fish out some
We can also say that a document is going to be published soon, for now.

Wesley Wiser said:

I've definitely seen people in the community ask how to do something and the response is "there's this cool RFC #nnn but it's not implemented yet". So it might make sense to align that section with that more clearly.

right. Though that kind of sentence belongs under under "Aspirations" and not "Concrete Initiatives", right?
@simulacrum rightly pointed out s/single core machines/single core builds/, for good reasons
Uh. I think there are probably some things that are concrete but yeah, most would be aspirational.
@Wesley Wiser do you think there are concrete ones, as in they have owners who plan to deliver something in 2022, that are worth adding to the list that's already there then?
To be clear to everyone: I am trying to walk the line between "laundry list of things" vs "valuable features that will get people excited, maybe excited enough to contribute."

No, I think the list is good as-is. The only question in my mind would be the const-generics/const-eval work. It seems nearly certain that we will make some progress there this year but I'm not sure we have clear goals for this year in that area.
(e.g. I think I ended up deciding that finishing off nll-migration mode fell into the "laundry list" category)
@Wesley Wiser and @simulacrum remarked on the need for code quality benchmarks
let me add an item to the end fo teh doc to discuss that
(I think I want to delegate the wordsmithing there, if nothing else.)
Editorial note: We should try to consistently use either GH or Zulip names when referring to people. I think we were mostly consistent in this regard but I will double check.
actually that's an interesting problem
Or perhaps use Zulip names but link to their GH profiles?
maybe use the Zulip name in the text and have the github name in the associated linkslink
yes exactly that

because right now people don't necessarily have a way to derive the Zulip name from the github name, even with the link, since not everyone has their zulip name on their github profile. (Does anyone have their zulip name there, if there's a mismatch? :lol: )
okay I can make that edit.
@Wesley Wiser do you think you will want to try to revise the Conclusion further?
if so, when?
Yeah, I do want to work on that a bit. I suspect I won't have time to do that until tomorrow morning.
https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/people/Mark-Simulacrum.toml (and similar for others, of course) will often list zulip and is keyed by github name, so that's one reason to prefer github
(If that's too late, I don't oppose posting what we have currently)
though I guess it's just the zulip id, not sure we can go from that to a name
we could put the zulip name in parentheses after the first introduction of a person
the same way I handled affiliation
it might be awkward for people like me where its the same. "pnkfelix (zulip: ibid)"? Probably even more confusing.
Maybe a list/table at the end of the post?
Maybe
I'm a little concerned that you might end up with a lot of parenthetical text the first time someone is mentioned.
Solution: We just create a Rust "profiles" page and link to that
Or maybe add the zulip name when mentioning that you can reach out to a person?
Oh that is the right answer

Jack Huey said:

Solution: We just create a Rust "profiles" page and link to that

That is basically the rust-lang/team repository.
(@bjorn3 's answer, that is)
Also I believe there is already a website. Probably outdated though.
okay lets plan on that approach

bjorn3 said:

Or maybe add the zulip name when mentioning that you can reach out to a person?

s/name/profile link/g
so then, meeting topics

bjorn3 said:

Also I believe there is already a website. Probably outdated though.

https://rustaceans.org/ by Nick Cameron.

Esteban K√ºber said:

bjorn3 said:

Or maybe add the zulip name when mentioning that you can reach out to a person?

s/name/profile link/g

is this a zulip profile link, you mean?
I'm not sure this is the most important point to discuss :smile:
so, meeting topics
"We should explicitly state that we are using emojis to categorize topics by the high-level area they relate to."
lets ask a bigger question: Are the emojis useful?
I like that it illustrates that some topics blur the line between themes
but I also worry from @Santiago Pastorino 's question that they might just be distracting?
I probably have a minor preference for swapping emojis out for a one-line 'For topics: ...' under the heading
or something like that.

pnkfelix said:

but I also worry from Santiago Pastorino 's question that they might just be distracting?

it's ok, I was wondering at the beginning but as you move on the meaning becomes more clear
well, the other thing that I think I like about them: I can skim the Table-of-Contents and see the rough distribution of themes across the different work areas
(I'm not 100% sure I want a table-of-contents in the post itself though. How do people feel about Table of Contents in a post like this? Its not a epic long thing like my MCVE post was)
I like that we only have at most 2 per item. I think if we had more than that, it would be pretty distracting.
If we keep the ToC ("table of contents"), I'd probably keep the emojis
I personally like the ToC
if the ToC is dropped, then I'd consider replacing the emojis with some other marker, like a keyword
okay. for now lets plan to keep the ToC then
Although, for the blog post, I think we might want to move it under the introduction.
Next up

"there should be a FAQ entry for ‚Äúwhy aren‚Äôt you putting in Monads‚Äù (half joke), where answer is ‚ÄúThe scope of this doc is largely restricted to Compiler Team issues. Language design work is done by the Language Design team.‚Äù"
I assume everyone is on board for that edit
if there are any other FAQ's that people think we need, please do speak up
"jackh726: Nit LendingItetator instead of StreamingIterator" good catch
I'll make that edit

• simulacrum: What are our goals for progress reporting, if any? Should we plan for a +1 year blog post, at least?
    • This 'planning' might mean something as simple as asking folks working on things to add PRs, etc. to a list we can then reference, or something more involved.

So at first when I read this remark, I thought it was asking about progress reporting at the level of this post, which I thought the document addressed: another post in ~June, and a year retrospective in ~November
Which, to be clear, is a timeline I pulled out of my butt at 2am last night
I would love to have a progress update post in June/July and then a final update in December/January.

pnkfelix said:

if there are any other FAQ's that people think we need, please do speak up

Should we have something beyond "jump on zulip, ping people and read the rustc dev guide"? Somewhere to provide links to the RFC repo and its process?
It might also be nice to have a GH tag for PRs that relate to the items here.

Esteban K√ºber said:

pnkfelix said:

if there are any other FAQ's that people think we need, please do speak up

Should we have something beyond "jump on zulip, ping people and read the rustc dev guide"? Somewhere to provide links to the RFC repo and its process?

good idea. Which pointers to give depend on the scope of what people want to do
though I will note: in some ways I'd prefer to have complete newcomers first talk to us on Zuloip
e.g. the RFC/MCP processes might be daunting to newcomers?
so maybe what we really need is a script for the respective owners to use when first engaging with a newcomer?

Wesley Wiser said:

It might also be nice to have a GH tag for PRs that relate to the items here.

oh that's a neat idea. Are you thinking of separate GH tags for each initiative?
or just one GH tag for "2022-compiler-initative" ?
I think one tag would be fine just for filtering purposes.
okay. yeah. yeah.
There are other A- tags that are probably sufficient beyond that.
I personally feel like that's hard
that might actually help with the progress reporting question that @simulacrum asked
Since sometimes PRs are somewhat, but not exactly related

Jack Huey said:

I personally feel like that's hard

its hard to make sense of the data from a 2022-compiler-initative tag?
It depends on what the goals of the tag are
if its to help us, at the midpoint, say "we've gotten N PR's that are driving forward items in this post"
and if we could also include that M/N of them are from newcomers
that would be pretty useful info
and sure, it might overcount

My personal goal for the tag would just be a way to filter all of the 10,000s (or whatever) PRs we get in 2022 to just the ones that might be worth mentioning on a blog post or something. Even if that list is 500 PRs (because people are quick to use the 2022-compiler-initive tag), that's still much easier to look through.
anyway, it is a question of what value the label provides
I think its worth a shot
if it doesn't go well, then hey, we don't do it again in 2023
we can always delete the label even

pnkfelix said:

  • simulacrum: What are our goals for progress reporting, if any? Should we plan for a +1 year blog post, at least?
    • This 'planning' might mean something as simple as asking folks working on things to add PRs, etc. to a list we can then reference, or something more involved.

@simulacrum what do you think about a label to resolve this problem?
Who's responsible for labeling? Author, reviewer, triage?
(anyone and everyone?)
I think we'd encourage authors and reviewers
I don't know if I'd try to put active triage effort into it
I suspect that it will quickly degenerate into noise, but I think it's probably the best idea for now
yeah. its tough. I'm already dealing with a proliferations of concrete lists that I try to review
we can potentially also consider asking/recommending owners to write progress updates on their or inside rust blogs, since that just 'generally seems good', but it's not too critical.
so I'm trying to avoid adding another one to the set
Also, since we're nearly 2 months into the year, do we go back and label merged PRs from this year?
(similar in scope to what we have at triage meetings, I think, length wise)
Or is Feb 2022 to Feb 2023

Jack Huey said:

Also, since we're nearly 2 months into the year, do we go back and label merged PRs from this year?

I wouldn't be opposed to people doing this
is it unfair? is it noisy? is it inaccurate? Yes to all
Yeah, if we can get each area owner to write three sentences describing work that's happened in their area in the past 6 months, we'd basically have a complete blog post.

simulacrum said:

we can potentially also consider asking/recommending owners to write progress updates on their or inside rust blogs, since that just 'generally seems good', but it's not too critical.

This seems better to me.

simulacrum said:

I suspect that it will quickly degenerate into noise, but I think it's probably the best idea for now

We won't know until we've done it, really. TBF, we can also derive the info by looking at each PR author and tagging new authors mechanically. It would be about as noisy/inaccurate as the manual tagging, I would think.

Jack Huey said:

simulacrum said:

we can potentially also consider asking/recommending owners to write progress updates on their or inside rust blogs, since that just 'generally seems good', but it's not too critical.

This seems better to me.

I worry its too heavy weight
but we can see
theres no harm in people doing it
We could also do like a 3 month trial run
and if it helps those owners get attention on their initiative, all the better
Label for 3 months, then have a few people write summaries
I just know how much effort I spend on my own blog posts
and see which one is better in terms of capturing progress
hmm.
outright planning to abandon use of the labels after three months doesn't sound right to me
or if 3 months is too little, 6 months
at that point, it really doesn't provide overall value
I don't think we want to do anything too heavy weight.
Lets plan to maybe talk more about this as we go
and for now we'll plan to start with a label
okay?
four minutes left in meeting time
one topic left
"pnkfelix: comments say we should highlight need for code quality benchmarks as part of performance work. What can/should we say on that front?"
@Wesley Wiser and @simulacrum , could you two maybe own adding text on this?
Sure
What is meant by "code quality benchmarks"
Happy to help edit or draft -- I was thinking something like 1-2 sentences at most.
cargo bench (lolbench) style
That's fine
@Wesley Wiser , you mentioned elsewhere that you wouldn't have time to work on this until tomorrow morning
We currently measure how fast rustc generates code but we don't really measure how good that code is.
that's fine with me. I obviously had hoped to get a Pull Request up for this on blog.rust-lang.org tonight, but really, I have no problem with waiting until Monday.
ah, so binary perf rather than compile perf?
object code perf

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser , you mentioned elsewhere that you wouldn't have time to work on this until tomorrow morning

I can add a few sentences about measuring CQ today. I'll just need more time than I have today to revise the conclusion.
("binary perf" to me sounds like"its a yes/no question)
I think it might be better to post on Monday or Tuesday anyway.
timeline wise: I believe rust-analyzer is tentatively scheduled for Monday, and release post for Thursday, so it sounds like it'll be a busy week if we post next week
busy week as in an overload for the readership?
or as in an overload for the blog post reviewers on core?
maybe, not sure. I think Tuesday is probably fine
no, review is fine
Let's see if we can round some stuff up for Wednesday and Friday and then blog.rust-lang.org can dominate the front page of /r/rust :laughing:
I'm happy to time it to get posted on Tuesday or Wednesday. I just want to know when the Pull Request should aim to go up in order to get approved for Tuesday or Wednesday

(I guess I do prefer Tuesday since I want more than 24 hours between this and the release blog post. But then again, maybe rust-analyzer would prefer more than 24 hours after their post and this one... :shrug: ...)
2-3 business days is typically a good launching point, I think getting it up later today with some adjustments coming in by Monday for tuesday seems good to me.
Okay. so the plan is: Make a pull request later today, but explicitly note that the Conclusion section is expcted to be expanded/revised... yes?
I'll leave a review to that effect when the PR goes up.
(and state in the Pull Request that we'd like it to go out on Tuesday)
Okay sounds great.Thaks y'all!
that is, thank you so much to @T-compiler/meeting for taking time to help with this.
have a great day/weekend. :wave:

pnkfelix said:

okay. for now lets plan to keep the ToC then

oh no, disaster: the Rust blog platform doesn't support [toc] markdown form! LOL
see also: https://github.com/kivikakk/comrak/issues/164
clearly I should add that issue to the Aspirations list. LOL

pnkfelix [said](https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic

okay. so lets leave it unlinked for now. We can edit the blog post after the fact when @**nnethercote** feels like its ready
````
Eh, just link it. I've added a note to the top of the draft explaining that it's a draft and expected to be complete by the end of next week. thanks
oh okay, that's great @nnethercote ! Will do!
And apologies for the formatting above :stuck_out_tongue:
you can edit after the fact, this aint bugzilla. :wink:
Fun fact: Bugzilla now supports editing of comments
hey, nick: your name will be under both the concrete initiative and the aspirational areas for Compiler Performance work (which I've now renamed to "Faster Builds" ...)
which section is more appropriate for your 2022 roadmap doc?

it strikes me as somewhat aspirational, but there's a fair amount of concrete work laid out in it. Its mostly a question of whether you think you and lqd could cover it all on your own, if you had to.
Probably concrete, big chunks of it at least will be happening
okay
We should btw make sure that the doc is read-only for the world, and similarly for any other hackmd style docs we post to blog.rust-lang.org, probably
(particularly for something likely to hit HN)
i'll reduce the permissions
I don't want anyone but me with edit access now anyway
okay this is so sad its hilarious
two of the emojis that wesley picked are skipped by the markdown processor when generating anchor tags.
but :working_on_it: is turned into %EF%B8%8F
For the perf roadmap anyone signed in can edit, I can't see how to change that
@nnethercote should be able to change it
or any owner
@nnethercote if you make me co-owner I can help you fix that
@Wesley Wiser @simulacrum filed as https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/pull/935
crud some of the links may be broken in my "table" of "contents"
I have to go, but I can try to fix that stuff over weekend. It will get done, one way or another
the main thing is that the important notable changes in content have been given their own commits
yeah, seems ok
typically I re-review blog posts from scratch anyway, since cohesion is important, and they're typically fairly short.
@pnkfelix It appears that @rust-compiler-team owns the perf roadmap, I think that's why I can't modify permissions
I guess we want the write permission set to "Owners"?
looks like that's fixed now

pnkfelix said:

Esteban K√ºber said:

bjorn3 said:

Or maybe add the zulip name when mentioning that you can reach out to a person?

s/name/profile link/g

is this a zulip profile link, you mean?

So, I still think linking to the zulip profile is the right thing, but: I don't see a way to actually get a URL with a link to it. :lol:

so far the closest thing i've been able to encode as an individualized url is the private messages with that individual, e..g this one for me: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/pm-with/116083-user116083
and if that's the best we can do, then that's okay. Maybe it is the right thing, in terms of immediately establishing contact
but it also means that the owners of each topic might get hit with a bunch of privmsg's they were not expecting

(At the very least, I think I'd want to distribute a "play book" for how the owners should respond to invididuals, in terms of "say hi! then find out more about what they want to work on, and migrate them as quickly as possible to a publicly visible topic in the appropriate stream so that more people can help onboard them.")

but still, part of me would prefer to funnel people directly into something like #new members > compiler 2022 (because then we wouldn't have to worry about newcomers messages going unaddressed because an individual isn't available to respond to a private message).
/me thinks

I think what I will do instead is: I'll put each persons Zulip name in the reach out section, like bjorn3 originally suggested. But in the "what do I do next" FAQ entry, I'll say that you should go to the #new members > compiler 2022 topic and say you want to help, including the initiative title and the zulip names of the owners.
You could have the PM message view as link. For example https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/pm-with/116083-user116083 for a PM with you.

bjorn3 said:

You could have the PM message view as link. For example https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/pm-with/116083-user116083 for a PM with you.

I considered this (and even gathered all the meta data I would need to do it), but I decided against it in the end. I think I want the newcomers to be funneled into #new members (and to just at-mention the owner(s)); my impression is that there is a strong support system there, and that's what we need for these people.
